title: IDOR in sending support email upon Verifying user business domain
vulnerability_information:
**Summary**
Trustpilot Business is making sure that you own the domain you have registered before continuing the process so they set 5 choices on how to verify. But there's another one, which is through sending a support ticket. By this you can send message to a support and hope to help you out.

There is a bit problem in this process. 1.) The `email` parameter is letting you to send email to another user, which don't own. 2.) The `phoneNumber` parameter is controllable. You can add text upto 94 characters enough to fool a user.

**How to reproduce**
First you need to register a valid account. If you don't own a domain it's Ok. There's a way to bypass the check. Just intercept the post request on `https://api.trustpilot.com/v1/business-requests/signup?utm_source=sign_up_link&utm_medium=business_login_page&utm_campaign=login` and modify the `email` parameter to your preferred email. Once set, check your email and click the verify.

If you've follow above step, you will be redirected to `https://businessapp.b2b.trustpilot.com/#/claim/` and here's where the magic happens. On the bottom there's a link called `Fill out this form`. Fill up the form and intercept the request. The request looks like this:
```
POST /v1/private/business-users/5cee035f00bf83001b207d67/activation/support HTTP/1.1
Host: api.trustpilot.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0
Accept: application/json, text/plain, */*
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Referer: https://businessapp.b2b.trustpilot.com/
Content-Type: application/json;charset=utf-8
Authorization: Bearer [reducted]
ApiKey: [reducted]
Content-Length: 182
Origin: https://businessapp.b2b.trustpilot.com
Connection: close

{"name":"test","email":"[reducted]","domain":"","phoneNumber":". Please follow this link to verify https://e-corp.ord","message":"test. pls ignore","locale":"en-US"}
```

Final step is to modify the `email` and `phoneNumber` parameter. This is will send an email you a target user and let you add a malicious link in the email.



POC: F498456

## Impact

IDOR which leads a phishing email to target any users
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary
Trustpilot Business is making sure that you own the domain you have registered before continuing the process so they set 5 choices on how to verify. But there's another one, which is through sending a support ticket. By this you can send message to a support and hope to help you out.

There is a bit problem in this process. 1.) The email parameter is letting you to send email to another user, which don't own. 2.) The phoneNumber parameter is controllable. You can add text upto 94 characters enough to fool a user.

How to reproduce
First you need to register a valid account. If you don't own a domain it's Ok. There's a way to bypass the check. Just intercept the post request on https://api.trustpilot.com/v1/business-requests/signup?utm_source=sign_up_link&utm_medium=business_login_page&utm_campaign=login and modify the email parameter to your preferred email. Once set, check your email and click the verify.

If you've follow above step, you will be redirected to https://businessapp.b2b.trustpilot.com/#/claim/ and here's where the magic happens. On the bottom there's a link called Fill out this form. Fill up the form and intercept the request. The request looks like this:

POST /v1/private/business-users/5cee035f00bf83001b207d67/activation/support HTTP/1.1
Host: api.trustpilot.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0
Accept: application/json, text/plain, */*
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Referer: https://businessapp.b2b.trustpilot.com/
Content-Type: application/json;charset=utf-8
Authorization: Bearer [reducted]
ApiKey: [reducted]
Content-Length: 182
Origin: https://businessapp.b2b.trustpilot.com
Connection: close

{"name":"test","email":"[reducted]","domain":"","phoneNumber":". Please follow this link to verify https://e-corp.ord","message":"test. pls ignore","locale":"en-US"}

Final step is to modify the email and phoneNumber parameter. This is will send an email you a target user and let you add a malicious link in the email.

POC: Screenshot_from_2019-05-28_23-18-23.png (F498456)

Impact

IDOR which leads a phishing email to target any users

Kind regards,

activities.message:
Hi @qwerty01 

I am having some difficulty in understanding what exactly the vulnerability you are reporting is.  Are you saying that an attacker is able to use the registration process to send emails to "victim" user's from the Trustpilot Support email account in a phishing attack?  Having a clear understanding of the issue you are reporting will help in reviewing your report.

Thanks,
@druth

PoC: F498919

activities.message:
Hi @qwerty01
  
Thank you for your submission! Unfortunately, this particular issue you reported is explicitly out of scope as outlined in the [Policy Page](https://hackerone.com/trustpilot):  

> - Social engineering (such as phishing, vishing, smishing) is strictly prohibited.
 
Your effort is nonetheless appreciated and we wish that you'll continue to research and submit any future security issues you find.

Best Regards,
@nasr0x01
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message:
Hi @nasr0x01,

With all your respect sir, I disagree that this is an informative. The bug is a logical error that uses your system to send an emails to a target user outside your company that includes a malicious link. Plus, the out of scope social engineering is the one that involves your company's staffs and/or contractors which the exploit didn't do.

Here's the scenario:
Attacker uses the bug I've found to send a support email. The support email has a auto reply (which is the bug) that will be send to the target user. There's no involvement of any of your stuffs/contractors in this. Now that the auto reply email was sent to the target, that target may have follow the malicious link. The impact is that the user's damage is cause by you sending malicious emails you everyone. 

I hope you understand what I mean.

Regards,
@qwerty01

Regards,
@qwerty01

activities.message:
In my understanding, the support email process is like this:

1. The registered user fills up the `Fill out this form` link in `https://businessapp.b2b.trustpilot.com/#/claim/`.
2. The supposed to be logical process of the `Fill out this form` is to: 

```
+-  Sends a support request to your stuff. 
+-  The support system has an auto reply email that will be send to the requestor.
```
3. The logical error here is the sending of auto reply email to the requestor. Attacker can send email to anyone 
without their consent.
4. There is no company staff involve in the exploit. The only involvement is that your staff will reply to that support request without knowing that the request was not sent by the target. 

This bug may have impact to your reputation by sending malicious email to everyone.

Regards,
@qwerty01
activities.markdown_message:
In my understanding, the support email process is like this:

  1. The registered user fills up the Fill out this form link in https://businessapp.b2b.trustpilot.com/#/claim/.
  2. The supposed to be logical process of the Fill out this form is to: 
+-  Sends a support request to your stuff. 
+-  The support system has an auto reply email that will be send to the requestor.
  1. The logical error here is the sending of auto reply email to the requestor. Attacker can send email to anyone without their consent.
  2. There is no company staff involve in the exploit. The only involvement is that your staff will reply to that support request without knowing that the request was not sent by the target.

This bug may have impact to your reputation by sending malicious email to everyone.

Regards,
@qwerty01

activities.message: If you're not convinced in my explanations, I would highly suggest, not to allow the system to send an auto reply email to anyone but the currently logged in user.
activities.markdown_message: If you're not convinced in my explanations, I would highly suggest, not to allow the system to send an auto reply email to anyone but the currently logged in user.
